intro: Prunus serrulata f. appendiculata, commonly known as the Japanese maple with appendiculate leaves, is a unique cultivar of the Japanese maple. It is characterized by its distinctive, elongated leaf lobes that extend beyond the main leaf blade, giving it a striking appearance. The plant is native to Japan and is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens. It typically grows to a height of 6 to 10 feet and produces small, showy flowers in spring. The foliage changes color in autumn, adding to its aesthetic appeal.
